item.content:encoded: Graphic: Cass Marshall/Polygon | Source Image: Ghost Ship Games The Huuli Hoarder sends me into a frenzy I play as a solo dwarf in Deep Rock Galactic: Survivor, armed with weapons, running around the mines of Hoxxes IV in search of valuable minerals. I gun down hordes of monsters, dig out supply caches, and upgrade my weapons so they fire even more hot death. But there‚Äôs one thing that always catches my attention and turns me into a homing missile. It‚Äôs a goofy little snail, and it brings me s...

item.content:encoded: Image: Stairway Games/Humble Games No matter what it is you like about the Sims, we‚Äôve got something for you There‚Äôs still not a game out there quite like the Sims. For over 20 years, the life simulation franchise has dominated its genre. Some similar games have been in development for years (and some like Paradox‚Äôs Life By You didn‚Äôt make it), but the Sims remains the biggest life simulation series out there. item.content:encoded: Image: Cicada Games Pushing blocks and yourself Sometimes, turning a linear game into an open world just makes sense. Whether it‚Äôs Elden Ring or Breath of the Wild, plenty of franchises have found that their core gameplay loops map well to an open world iteration. With Elden Ring, you can disperse the intense FromSoft difficulty across a map that invites players to ‚Äúgit gud‚Äù at their own pace. With Breath of the Wild, the entire world is now a dungeon, every hill and valley a puzzle. Playing b...

item.content:encoded: A Little to the Left | Image: Max Inferno/Secret Mode I just want to keep playing The satisfaction of solving a puzzle is inherent. You learn the rules of the game, then you‚Äôre presented with a challenge that tests your knowledge of those rules. The predictability is calming, and hearing the game‚Äôs click or bell or ring when you‚Äôve solved each puzzle is a serotonin bump I‚Äôve grown a bit reliant upon. But sometimes I can‚Äôt figure out a puzzle, and in those situations, I‚Äôm grateful for games tha...

item.title: The platonic ideal of tabletop terrain is finally back in circulation with the reboot of Heroscape | Polygon - Gaming
item.description: Photo: Charlie Hall/Polygon After Hasbro‚Äôs crowdfunding effort failed, Renegade Game Studio stepped in to save the reboot Heroscape, the beloved miniatures wargame, is finally back on the market. Po...
item.content:encoded: Photo: Charlie Hall/Polygon After Hasbro‚Äôs crowdfunding effort failed, Renegade Game Studio stepped in to save the reboot Heroscape, the beloved miniatures wargame, is finally back on the market. Polygon had a chance to unbox (but not play) the new Heroscape: Age of Annihilation Master Set and we are delighted to report that even after its rocky reveal in 2022, the reboot looks pretty solid. Better still is the fact that its glorious, chunky terrain will soon be available for everyone to enjoy...

For me, it was both great news about a neat game finally escaping the limbo of Apple Arcade exclusivity, but also a moment where I finally asked myself a Big Question I had been avoiding: Why do I even bother with Apple Arcade in th...

item.title: The voices of your favorite video game characters are going on strike | Polygon - Gaming
item.description: Image: Insomniac Games/Sony Interactive Entertainment Video game performers last went on strike in 2016 The Screen Actors Guild-American Federation of Television and Radio Artists announced Thursday...
item.content:encoded: Image: Insomniac Games/Sony Interactive Entertainment Video game performers last went on strike in 2016 The Screen Actors Guild-American Federation of Television and Radio Artists announced Thursday that video game performers will go on strike on July 26 at 12:01 a.m. More than 2,500 video game performers ‚Äî a group that includes voice actors, motion capture performers, and others ‚Äî head to the picket line after nearly two years of negotiations with a major video game companies. The biggest sti...
